qas.question: By mid November of 1940 how many incendiaries were dropped on London?
What locations suffered strong diversionary tactics?
In September how many railway hits were there in Great Britain?
What did the Ministry of Home Security fail to discover?

answers.text: the slightest sign of a break in morale

qas.question: About how many civilians were injured in September and October?

context: By mid-November 1940, when the Germans adopted a changed plan, more than 13,000 short tons (12,000 t) of high explosive and nearly <a0_0>1,000,000<a0_0/> incendiaries had fallen on London. Outside the capital, there had been widespread harassing activity by single aircraft, as well as fairly strong diversionary attacks on <a1_0>Birmingham, Coventry and Liverpool<a1_0/>, but no major raids. The London docks and railways communications had taken a heavy pounding, and much damage had been done to the railway system outside. In September, there had been <a2_0>no less than 667<a2_0/> hits on railways in Great Britain, and at one period, between 5,000 and 6,000 wagons were standing idle from the effect of delayed action bombs. But the great bulk of the traffic went on; and Londoners—though they glanced apprehensively each morning at the list of closed stretches of line displayed at their local station, or made strange detours round back streets in the buses—still got to work. For all the destruction of life and property, the observers sent out by the Ministry of Home Security failed to discover <a3_0>the slightest sign of a break in morale<a3_0/>. More than 13,000 civilians had been killed, and almost <a4_0>20,000<a4_0/> injured, in September and October alone, but the death toll was much less than expected. In late 1940, Churchill credited the shelters:
